awd_titl_txt: SNM: Continuous Synthesis and Stabilization of Nanoparticles in a Carbon Matrix Using Rapid Thermal Shock
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoparticles (NPs) hosted in a conductive matrix are important for a range of applications from electrochemical energy storage, to catalysis to energetic devices. However, manufacturing NPs in high quality and at high efficiency remains as a challenge. Aiming to address this challenge, this Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) award plans to investigate a scalable nanomanufacturing and stabilization method for NPs embedded within a conductive matrix through a unique thermal shock process. This project can lead to an ultra-fast and facile NP nanomanufacturing approach in a carbon matrix based on high-temperature (up to 3000 K) thermal shock within 10 milliseconds. The relatively simple approach to manufacturing NPs in a conductive matrix by heating provides an ideal teaching tool for high school and undergraduate students. Involving these students in this project helps increase their interests in science and technology and offering training opportunities to gain research experience. Cyber-based outreach activities via iMechanica.org will also further broaden the impacts of the proposed research and educational activities.

The project originates from the team's recent demonstration of ultra-fast (<0.01 s) synthesis of uniformly distributed metal NPs within a conductive matrix by Joule heating, followed by subsequent rapidly quenching. In this project, the fundamentals of ultra-fast, in situ NP formation in conductive matrices using aluminum NP and reduced-graphene oxide or carbon nanofiber matrix as a model system will be investigated. The fundamental understanding of the process will be applied to investigate the scale-up synthesis of the NPs in a conductive matrix, focusing on overcoming major scale-up roadblocks, such as uniform distribution throughout the thickness direction, and low cost, followed by designing and benchmarking scalability with a lab-scale roll-to-roll processing setup. The team will also demonstrate, evaluate and optimize the roll-to-roll system to fabricate aluminum NP composites, and investigate the key nanomanufacturing-related issues, such as fabrication rate, throughput, product quality, reproducibility, yield, efficiency and cost.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project investigated scalable synthesis, stabilization, and application of nanoparticles (NPs) supported on conductive substrate using novel thermal shock based synthesis, diagnostic characterization, and modeling. Throughout the entire project, the UMD teams (Dr. Hu, Dr. Li, and Dr. Zachariah) have collaborated closely. The major advances in knowledge from the project include: (1) non-equilibrium, ultra-fast process of NP self-assembly and stabilization in a conductive matrix by high-temperature thermal shock; (2) mechanistic understanding of NP formation and the role of defects in stabilization, through extensive characterization and modeling; (3) manufacturing science of high-speed, roll-to-roll processing, including yield, uniformity, statistic distribution and size distribution. The methodology and knowledge of ultra-fast NP formation on various carbon substrates can be applied to a broad range of other nanomaterials.

During the project, the team has published 23 papers on high profile journals, including those on Nature and Science. The team has also filed 1 patent about thermal shock based nanoparticle synthesis. Below is a detailed list of publications and patents.

Publications under this NSF funding:

1. Yao, Y. et al. High-entropy nanoparticles: Synthesis-structure-property relationships and data-driven discovery. Science 376, eabn3103 (2022).

2. Yao, Y. et al. Extreme mixing in nanoscale transition metal alloys. Matter 4, 2340-2353 (2021).

3. Yang, Y. et al. Determining the three-dimensional atomic structure of an amorphous solid. Nature 592, 60?64 (2021).

4. Qiao, Y. et al. Continuous Fly-Through High-Temperature Synthesis of Nanocatalysts. Nano Lett. 21, 4517?4523 (2021).

5. Huang, Z. et al. Direct observation of the formation and stabilization of metallic nanoparticles on carbon supports. Nat. Commun. 11, 6373 (2020).

6. Wu, M. et al. Hierarchical Polyelemental Nanoparticles as Bifunctional Catalysts for Oxygen Evolution and Reduction Reactions. Adv. Energy Mater. 2001119, 20?23 (2020).

7. Qiao, Y.; et al. Thermal Shock Synthesis of Nanocatalyst by 3D‐Printed Miniaturized Reactors. Small 2000509 (2020).

8. Yang, Y. et al. Rapid Laser Pulse Synthesis of Supported Metal Nanoclusters with Kinetically Tunable Size and Surface Density for Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution. ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 3, 2959?2968 (2020).

9. Yang, Y. et al. Aerosol Synthesis of High Entropy Alloy Nanoparticles. Langmuir 36, 1985?1992 (2020).

10. Yao, Y. et al. Ultrafast, Controllable Synthesis of Sub-Nano Metallic Clusters through Defect Engineering. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 11, 29773?29779 (2019).

11. Jiao, M. et al. Fly-through synthesis of nanoparticles on textile and paper substrates. Nanoscale 11, 6174?6181 (2019).

12. Chen, Y. et al. Millisecond synthesis of CoS nanoparticles for highly efficient overall water splitting. Nano Res. 12, 2259-2267 (2019).

13. Chen, Y. et al. One-Step, Catalyst-Free, Scalable in Situ Synthesis of Single-Crystal Aluminum Nanowires in Confined Graphene Space. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 11, 6009?6014 (2019).

14. Chen, Y. et al. Nanomanufacturing of graphene nanosheets through nano-hole opening and closing. Mater. Today 24, 26?32 (2019).

15. Li, Y. et al. In Situ ?Chainmail Catalyst? Assembly in Low-Tortuosity, Hierarchical Carbon Frameworks for Efficient and Stable Hydrogen Generation. Adv. Energy Mater. 1801289, 1801289 (2018).

16. Zhou, Y. et al. Tuning the High-Temperature Wetting Behavior of Metals toward Ultrafine Nanoparticles. Angew. Chemie Int. Ed. 57, 2625?2629 (2018).

17. Chen, F. et al. High-Temperature Atomic Mixing toward Well-Dispersed Bimetallic Electrocatalysts. Adv. Energy Mater. 1800466, 1800466 (2018).

18. Yang, C. et al. Ultrafine Silver Nanoparticles for Seeded Lithium Deposition toward Stable Lithium Metal Anode. Adv. Mater. 29, 1702714 (2017).

19. Xu, S. et al. Universal, in Situ Transformation of Bulky Compounds into Nanoscale Catalysts by High-Temperature Pulse. Nano Lett. 17, 5817?5822 (2017).

20. Yao, Y. et al. In Situ High Temperature Synthesis of Single-Component Metallic Nanoparticles. ACS Cent. Sci. 3, 294?301 (2017).

21. Li, Y. et al. In Situ, Fast, High-Temperature Synthesis of Nickel Nanoparticles in Reduced Graphene Oxide Matrix. Adv. Energy Mater. 7, 1601783 (2017).

22. Chen, Y. et al. FeS 2 Nanoparticles Embedded in Reduced Graphene Oxide toward Robust, High-Performance Electrocatalysts. Adv. Energy Mater. 7, 1700482 (2017).

23. Chen, Y. et al. Rapid, in Situ Synthesis of High Capacity Battery Anodes through High Temperature Radiation-Based Thermal Shock. Nano Lett. 16, 5553?5558 (2016).

Patent under this NSF funding:

1. L. Hu, Y. Chen, Y. Yao. ?NANOPARTICLES AND SYSTEMS AND METHODS FOR SYNTHESIZING NANOPARTICLES THROUGH THERMAL SHOCK?, US20180369771A1. Filed Jun.22, 2018.

Broader Impacts:

This project offered a number of training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. A total of 7 graduate students and 2 postdocs are supported by this project, and many undergraduate students also participated in the research, mainly working on the roll-to-roll setup as their academic training project. In addition, the relative simplicity of fabricating NPs in a conductive matrix by heating provided an ideal teaching tool for high school and undergraduate students in the STEM and REU programs held during the project period.


Last Modified: 09/09/2022
Modified by: Liangbing Hu
